### Async - Await

Async/await is a syntax feature in JavaScript that allows you to write **asynchronous**
code that looks and behaves more like synchronous code. It is built on top of **`Promises`**
and makes it easier to write, read and handle asynchronous operations.

- **Async** :
  The async keyword is used to declare an asynchronous function. This function
  returns a **Promise** object, which represents the eventual completion (or
  failure) of the operation.

- **Await**:
  Inside the asynchronous function, you can use the await keyword to wait for the
  result of an asynchronous operation.

Here's an example of how to use a Async/Await to call an API:

```js title="index.js"
{/* async means function is asynchronous */}
async function getData() {

  /* await means wait for promiseto be resolve or reject */
  const response = await fetch("https://example.com/api");
  const data = await response.json();
  return data;
}

const data = await getData();
console.log(data);
```

### What is Promise?

A Promise is an object that represents a value that
may not be available yet but will be resolved at some point in the future.
Promises are used to handle asynchronous operations, such as network requests or
file system access, and they make it easier to write asynchronous code that is
easier to read and maintain.

A Promise has three states:

> **pending**: When a Promise is created, it starts in the pending state.

> **fulfilled/rejected**: Once the Promise is resolved, it can either be fulfilled with a value or rejected with an error.

This is how what code looks like to call an API without Async/Await:

```js title="index.js"
function getData() {
  return new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
    fetch("https://example.com/api")
      .then((response) => {
        if (response.ok) {
          resolve(response.json());
        } else {
          reject("Error fetching data");
        }
      })
      .catch((error) => {
        reject(error.message);
      });
  });
}

getData()
  .then((data) => {
    console.log(data);
  })
  .catch((error) => {
    console.error(error);
  });
```
